importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the lawsuit filing and the public announcement of Arizona's legal action against the House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson's refusal to swear in Adelita Grijalva.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Adelita Grijalva won her congressional race, which led to the dispute over her seating and the subsequent legal action.

keyTakeAways: Arizona's attorney general, Kris Mayes, has sued the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson's refusal to administer the oath of office to newly elected Representative Adelita Grijalva.
The lawsuit claims that the Constitution does not grant the Speaker the authority to delay seating a duly elected representative simply because the House is in a recess or has gone out of session.
Speaker Mike Johnson cites a precedent set by former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who delayed swearing in newly elected representatives after recesses, as justification for his actions.
Johnson claims he will administer the oath on the first day of the House's return to legislative session, indicating a willingness to comply once the session resumes.
The lawsuit accuses Johnson of using the delay as a political maneuver to avoid a petition concerning Jeffrey Epstein records and to strengthen his position in budget and appropriations negotiations.
This case raises constitutional questions about the authority of the Speaker to block the seating of newly elected officials during recess or post-recess periods.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Arizona’s Attorney General Kris Mayes has filed a lawsuit against the U.S. House of Representatives, challenging Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Representative Adelita Grijalva, who won her seat in late September 2025. The lawsuit asserts that the Constitution does not allow the Speaker to deny a duly elected member office simply because the House is in recess. Johnson claims he is following a precedent established by former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, stating he will administer the oath upon the House’s return to regular session. However, the lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s delay is politically motivated—aimed at avoiding a petition for Epstein-related records and strengthening his position in budget negotiations. This case raises critical constitutional questions about the power of the Speaker to control the seating of elected officials.
title: Arizona Sues Over Mike Johnson’s Refusal to Swear In Adelita Grijalva
